title: How to Purchase and Care for Phalaenopsis Orchids

steps.headline: First, consider your source.
steps.description: While five dollar orchids at IKEA may seem appealing, they are usually stressed plants given minimal care. Stick with a greenhouse, or orchid specialty store for healthy plants.

steps.headline: Next, choose from the selection, looking for:
steps.description: Dark green leaves with no discoloration or broken sections. A row of buds set, with one or two open flowers (to get an idea of color/pattern). Roots may be visible outside of the pot. This is natural and does not matter either way.

steps.headline: If buying an orchid in winter: have it sleeved before walking out to the car!
steps.description: A sudden severe drop in temperature can make Orchids drop their buds!

steps.headline: Sunlight: Position in an east facing window, or a southern window with indirect exposure.
Water: Water thoroughly every 7-10 days, to allow for drying in between.
steps.description: Humidity should be around 60%. If needed, use a tray of water with a layer of pebbles underneath the pot.

steps.headline: Keep it at lower temperatures.
steps.description: Temperature: Day - 75–85 °F (24–29 °C), Night – Lower, but not below 60 °F (16 °C).

steps.headline: Fertilizer:  Fertilize “weakly, weekly.” Use ¼ strength dilution Jack's Classic Orchid Fertilizer.
Repotting: Pot on every two years, just after a flowering period has finished.
steps.description: Use Osmunda Fiber, Orchid Bark Mix, or Sphagnum Moss. Many nurseries offer this service, as repotting orchids can be tricky.

steps.headline: Reblooming: Occurs naturally every 8-10 months.
steps.description: If no stem appears, bring to slightly sunnier position, and switch fertilizer to Jack's Classic Orchid Bloom Booster.

text: Choosing an Orchid First, consider your source. While five dollar orchids at IKEA may seem appealing, they are usually stressed plants given minimal care. Stick with a greenhouse, or orchid specialty store for healthy plants. Next, choose from the selection, looking for: Dark green leaves with no discoloration or broken sections. A row of buds set, with one or two open flowers (to get an idea of color/pattern). Roots may be visible outside of the pot. This is natural and does not matter either way. If buying an orchid in winter: have it sleeved before walking out to the car! A sudden severe drop in temperature can make Orchids drop their buds! Basic Care Sunlight: Position in an east facing window, or a southern window with indirect exposure.  Water: Water thoroughly every 7-10 days, to allow for drying in between. Humidity should be around 60%. If needed, use a tray of water with a layer of pebbles underneath the pot. Keep it at lower temperatures. Temperature: Day - 75–85 °F (24–29 °C), Night – Lower, but not below 60 °F (16 °C). Fertilizer:  Fertilize “weakly, weekly.” Use ¼ strength dilution Jack's Classic Orchid Fertilizer.  Repotting: Pot on every two years, just after a flowering period has finished. Use Osmunda Fiber, Orchid Bark Mix, or Sphagnum Moss. Many nurseries offer this service, as repotting orchids can be tricky. Reblooming: Occurs naturally every 8-10 months. If no stem appears, bring to slightly sunnier position, and switch fertilizer to Jack's Classic Orchid Bloom Booster.
